title: Paper Thoughts — Read, Write, Chain (Tales to Tokens)

sub_fields.title: Who you’re targeting, how you’ll reach them, and why this matters for Cardano?
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
Our project targets three interconnected audiences that Cardano currently struggles to reach:



Primary: Locals and everyday readers (Age 25-65)

These are our 576 existing book club members and similar communities—people who value stories, heritage, and craft but have zero blockchain experience. They're literate, civic-minded, and care deeply about preserving community memory. They don't respond to technical tutorials about DeFi or development tools, but they will engage with meaningful cultural projects. When we frame Cardano as a tool to make their grandmother's stories permanent and accessible, suddenly blockchain becomes relevant to their lives.



Secondary: Elders and tradition-bearers (Age 60+)

Community elders hold irreplaceable oral histories, proverbs, folklore, and local knowledge. They're often excluded from technology conversations entirely. We're creating a bridge where their participation is honored (through stipends and respectful documentation) and their stories become permanent digital artifacts. Many have grandchildren who might help them understand "their story is now on the blockchain forever"—creating intergenerational Cardano awareness.



Tertiary: Young creatives and animators (Age 18-35)

Through our comic contest, we engage artists, illustrators, and animators who work in visual storytelling. This demographic is digitally fluent but may see Cardano as "just another crypto project." By inviting them to transform elders' stories into art that gets minted as NFTs, we show them Cardano's cultural utility—not just financial speculation.



Why this matters:



1. Solves the "cold start" problem for non-technical adoption



Cardano's current onboarding materials overwhelmingly target developers, DeFi users, or people already crypto-curious. The average person sees wallets, seed phrases, and staking rewards—abstract concepts that feel risky and irrelevant. Our project creates a warm doorway: "Come record your grandmother's recipe, and we'll show you how to make it permanent on Cardano." The blockchain action becomes secondary to the cultural value, removing psychological barriers.



We're not asking people to "buy crypto"—we're inviting them to preserve heritage, then gently showing them: "Here's how Cardano helps make this permanent." This reframes the entire value proposition.



2. Demonstrates real-world utility beyond finance



Every mainstream criticism of blockchain asks: "But what's it actually FOR?" Cultural preservation is a clear, emotionally resonant answer. When someone can point to their grandfather's story minted as an NFT and say, "This can never be lost now, and anyone can access it for free," that's tangible utility. It's not speculative—it's immediate and meaningful.



This project produces artifacts (oral histories, micro-journals, comics) that live beyond the grant period and demonstrate Cardano's capability to preserve cultural memory permanently and transparently.



3. Creates long-term, values-aligned community members



People who enter Cardano through cultural preservation aren't looking for quick profits—they're mission-driven. They care about decentralization, permanence, and public goods. These are exactly the kinds of long-term community members Cardano needs: people who will stake responsibly, participate in governance thoughtfully, and evangelize Cardano to others with similar values.



Our 200-wallet target isn't just about numbers—it's about bringing in 200 people who understand why decentralization matters because they've seen how centralized platforms can disappear and take cultural memory with them.



4. Generates compelling ecosystem narratives



Cardano needs stories that inspire non-technical audiences. "We preserved 30 elder interviews on Cardano" is a story that resonates with journalists, educators, policymakers, and everyday people. It's shareable content that humanizes the technology.



Each animated comic we produce becomes a mini-documentary about Cardano's cultural impact. Each micro-journal minted becomes a proof point. These narratives attract other cultural organizations, universities, and NGOs who might consider Cardano for their own heritage projects.



5. Validates Cardano's sustainability and permanence claims



Cardano positions itself as the sustainable, long-term blockchain. What better validation than cultural preservation? We're literally saying: "We trust Cardano to hold our ancestors' stories forever." That endorsement—from everyday people, not crypto influencers—carries weight.



6. Unlocks partnership opportunities with institutions



Our library partnerships demonstrate how Cardano can integrate with trusted community institutions. When local libraries host "Cardano minting clinics," that's mainstream legitimacy. It opens doors for other public institutions (schools, museums, community centers) to explore Cardano without feeling like they're endorsing speculation.



7. Strategic Timing:



Right now, Cardano is investing in governance, sustainability, and real-world impact. Our project aligns perfectly with these priorities. While other chains focus on financial products, Cardano can lead on cultural and social applications. This is competitive differentiation that matters to regulators, institutions, and the broader public.



8. Scale Potential:



If successful, this model is replicable across thousands of communities globally. Every town, diaspora group, indigenous community, and cultural organization faces the same challenge: preserving disappearing oral traditions. We're creating an open-source playbook (all materials CC-licensed) that others can adapt. One successful 9-month pilot can inspire 100 similar projects—each bringing hundreds of new users to Cardano through culture rather than speculation.



In summary: We're targeting the vast majority of humanity that blockchain has failed to reach—people who care about stories, not staking yields—and we're showing them why Cardano matters to the things they already love. That's how you build a billion-user blockchain: one grandmother's story at a time.

sub_fields.title: Provide a list of key activities of your project:
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
ACTIVITY 1: MONTHLY READING SALONS (9 sessions)



What: Moderated online discussions featuring authors, historians, cultural guests, or themed readings from our community. Each 90-minute session is recorded and published with transcripts.



Rationale: Reading salons are the consistent heartbeat of the project, they keep our community engaged monthly and create regular touchpoints for recruitment into deeper activities (cohorts, minting clinics). Unlike one-off events, monthly rhythm builds habit and trust. Salons also produce low-effort content (recordings) that extend reach beyond live attendees. Each salon ends with a 10-minute "Cardano moment"—a soft introduction to wallets or upcoming minting opportunities—normalizing blockchain conversation in a cultural context rather than a technical one.



Cardano connection: Salons create the awareness funnel. Attendees who enjoy the cultural content become candidates for wallet creation. The recurring format means we get multiple chances to convert interested participants rather than relying on a single event.



Deliverable: 9 recorded sessions, transcripts, 1,500+ total attendee hours across the project.





ACTIVITY 2: CULTURAL PRESERVATION WRITING COHORTS (3 cohorts, ~15 participants each)



What: Three quarterly cohorts where participants learn oral-history interviewing techniques, conduct and transcribe elder interviews, and receive editorial mentorship to turn raw recordings into polished written pieces. Each cohort culminates in a published micro-journal issue.



Rationale: This is the project's core value creation. Cohorts give participants structured learning, accountability, and community while producing tangible cultural preservation outputs. The 6-8 week cohort model creates intimacy—participants bond over shared purpose, making them more likely to support each other through "scary" first blockchain experiences.



By focusing on elders specifically, we're capturing knowledge at risk of disappearing. Each interview preserved is irreplaceable cultural data. By publishing it (print + digital + blockchain), we maximize accessibility while demonstrating Cardano's permanence.



Cardano connection: Cohort completion = eligibility to mint the micro-journal NFT as a contributor. This creates earned achievement—people mint with pride because they helped create the content. It's far more meaningful than minting a random NFT for a tutorial.



Deliverable: 3 micro-journals (30 contributors total, 30 elder interviews documented).





ACTIVITY 3: LIBRARY PARTNERSHIPS & "PAPER THOUGHTS CORNERS"



What: Formal partnerships with 3 local libraries/community centers. Each partner hosts physical "Paper Thoughts Corners" with printed micro-journals, oral-history guides, and Cardano beginner materials. Libraries host in-person reading circles and offer "blockchain help desk" hours where staff assist with wallet setup and minting.



Rationale: Libraries are trusted, neutral community institutions—perfect for legitimizing blockchain activities for people who distrust tech companies. By anchoring our project in physical spaces, we reach people who don't engage with online-only content (especially elders). Libraries also provide free, accessible venues for in-person support, which is critical for onboarding non-technical users.



Physical presence creates permanence beyond the 9-month grant. Even after funding ends, materials remain in libraries, and trained staff can continue basic support.



Cardano connection: Library-hosted minting clinics remove the "I'm doing something risky online alone" fear. Having a librarian say, "Yes, this is legitimate, let me help you" is powerful social proof. Libraries can also host ongoing staking information sessions after the grant ends.



Deliverable: 3 partner libraries with physical corners, 6 in-person events, 300 printed guides distributed.





ACTIVITY 4: ORAL-HISTORY DIGITAL ARCHIVE



What: Professional recording, transcription, and metadata tagging of 30 select elder interviews. Published as a searchable, open-access digital archive with proper consent, attribution, and accessibility features (audio + text).



Rationale: The archive is our most enduring public good—it's useful to researchers, educators, families, and future generations regardless of blockchain adoption. By creating something with clear immediate value, we earn trust to introduce Cardano concepts later.



Metadata and searchability make the archive actually usable (many oral history projects fail because they're just unlabeled audio files). Professional quality signals respect for elders' contributions.



Cardano connection: Archive metadata references where each story's commemorative NFT lives on Cardano, creating a bridge between traditional web archive and blockchain verification. People searching the archive learn, "Oh, this story is also permanently recorded on Cardano"—educational exposure without forcing participation.



Deliverable: 30 interviews (15+ hours of audio), transcripts, public archive website.





ACTIVITY 5: COMIC CONTEST & ANIMATION



What: Open call for comics/illustrations based on collected oral histories. Expected 30 submissions, 4 finalists selected by community vote, 2 winners professionally animated into 2-5 minute shorts. Final screening event with community and libraries.



Rationale: Comics and animation attract a younger, more diverse creative demographic than traditional writing. The contest generates excitement, social sharing, and cross-promotion. By requiring submissions to be based on collected stories, we ensure fidelity to source material while allowing creative interpretation.



Animation is highly shareable—a 3-minute animated folk tale travels much further on social media than a written micro-journal. It becomes a marketing asset for Cardano's cultural impact that lasts beyond the project.



Cardano connection: Contest finalists and winners receive commemorative NFT badges minted on Cardano—their first blockchain credential. Winners' animations are also minted, creating on-chain provenance for the art. Animators can showcase "I created NFT artwork on Cardano" in portfolios, seeding awareness in creative industries.



Deliverable: 30 submissions, 4 finalists, 2 animated shorts, community screening, all minted as NFTs.





ACTIVITY 6: GUIDED MINTING CLINICS & WALLET WORKSHOPS



What: Step-by-step technical support sessions timed after major milestones (cohort completions, salon highlights, contest results). Clinics walk participants through downloading a wallet, securing seed phrases, receiving test ADA, and minting their first NFT (micro-journal or participation badge). Follow-up workshops introduce staking basics.



Rationale: This is where cultural interest converts to actual adoption. Without hands-on support, most non-technical people abandon wallet setup at the first confusing step. Clinics provide live troubleshooting, reassurance, and community accountability ("everyone's doing it together, I'm not alone").



Timing clinics after milestones means people have earned something they care about (contributor credit, contest entry) before attempting technical steps—motivation is high.



Cardano connection: This activity IS the Cardano adoption. 200 wallets created, 300 NFTs minted, 100 staking wallets—these are our core metrics. Every person who successfully mints becomes living proof that "regular people can do this."



Deliverable: 6 guided clinics (3 post-cohort, 2 post-salons, 1 final), wallet setup guides, video tutorials.





ACTIVITY 7: PUBLIC DOCUMENTATION & FINAL IMPACT REPORT



What: Transparent, ongoing documentation of all activities, metrics, challenges, and learnings. Final comprehensive impact report published openly with replication toolkit for other communities.



Rationale: Accountability builds trust with funders and community. Real-time documentation also creates content for social media and progress updates, maintaining engagement throughout 9 months.



The replication toolkit is critical—our success only scales if others can copy it. By open-sourcing all materials, guides, and workflows (CC-licensed), we maximize the project's long-term impact beyond our community.



Cardano connection: The report becomes a case study Cardano Foundation can point to: "Here's proof that cultural onboarding works, here's the playbook." Other Catalyst proposers can adapt our model for their regions/cultures.



Deliverable: Monthly progress updates, final 50-page impact report, replication toolkit with all templates and guides.





RATIONALE SUMMARY:



Every activity balances cultural value (immediate, tangible benefit to participants) with blockchain adoption (gentle, supported onboarding). We never lead with Cardano—we lead with stories, then show how Cardano enhances preservation. This sequencing is critical for reaching non-technical audiences who would flee from a "blockchain project" but embrace a "cultural preservation project that happens to use blockchain."

sub_fields.title: What are your success metrics?
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
We measure success across three dimensions: Cultural Impact (did we preserve heritage?), Community Engagement (did we build something sustainable?), and Cardano Adoption (did we onboard new users?). Each metric is SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) and tied to project activities.





DIMENSION 1: CULTURAL PRESERVATION OUTPUTS



Metric 1.1: 30 oral-history interviews recorded, transcribed, and published



Target: 30 completed interviews (10 per cohort)  

Measurement: Count of published interviews in digital archive  

Rationale: This is our core cultural deliverable—the irreplaceable knowledge we're preserving. 30 is ambitious but achievable with 3 cohorts of ~15 participants (not all will complete interviews, but cohort structure provides accountability). Each interview represents 1-2 hours of elder storytelling captured forever.



Success criteria:

- Excellent: 30+ interviews, diverse topics (folklore, recipes, historical events, proverbs)

- Good: 25-29 interviews with high audio quality

- Acceptable: 20-24 interviews (indicates recruitment challenges)





Metric 1.2: 3 published micro-journal issues (print + PDF + minted as NFTs)



Target: 3 journals, 24-32 pages each, featuring curated interview excerpts, essays, and community reflections  

Measurement: Published journals (300 printed copies, PDF downloads, NFT mint count)  

Rationale: Micro-journals transform raw interviews into accessible, beautifully designed cultural artifacts. They're shareable, collectible, and serve as tangible proof of project output. Minting them as limited NFTs creates scarcity and collectibility while introducing participants to blockchain.



Success criteria:

- 3 journals published on schedule (months 3, 5, 8)

- Each includes 8-12 documented stories

- Distributed to libraries and community hubs





Metric 1.3: 2 animated oral-history shorts produced and screened



Target: Two 2-5 minute professionally animated shorts based on contest-winning comics  

Measurement: Video files published, screening attendance, online views  

Rationale: Animation creates the most shareable, emotionally engaging output. A 3-minute animated folk tale can reach thousands on social media, attracting people who wouldn't read a journal. This extends project impact far beyond immediate participants.



Success criteria:

- 2 high-quality animations completed

- Screened at community event (50+ attendees)

- 2,000+ combined views online within 3 months





DIMENSION 2: COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT & SUSTAINABILITY



Metric 2.1: 4,000 cumulative attendee-hours across all activities



Target: 4,000 total participant-hours (salons, cohorts, events, clinics)  

Measurement: Attendance tracking (sign-ins, video analytics for recordings, event attendance)  

Rationale: This measures total community engagement—not just unique individuals but sustained involvement. We calculate:

- 9 salons × 60 avg live attendees × 1.5 hours = 810 hours

- 9 salon recordings × 150 views × 1 hour = 1,350 hours

- 3 cohorts × 15 people × 40 hours each = 1,800 hours

- Events, clinics, screenings = ~240 hours

Total: ~4,200 hours (target 4,000 to be conservative)



Success criteria:

- Exceeds 4,000 hours (strong engagement)

- 3,000-4,000 hours (acceptable)

- Below 3,000 hours (indicates need to improve marketing/accessibility)





Metric 2.2: 120 repeat participants from 576-member community



Target: 120 community members attend 2+ activities  

Measurement: Participant tracking across activities (with privacy protection—using anonymized IDs)  

Rationale: Repeat participation indicates we're building genuine community, not just one-off attendance. 120 represents ~21% of our existing 576 members deeply engaging—a healthy conversion for sustained involvement.



Success criteria:

-  120+ repeat participants (building core community)

-  At least 30 participants complete full cohort + attend salons + mint NFTs (super-engaged members)





Metric 2.3: 3 library partnerships with trained staff



Target: 3 libraries with active "Paper Thoughts Corners" and at least 1 trained staff member each  

Measurement: MOUs signed, training completion certificates, active corners photographed  

Rationale: Library partnerships ensure project longevity beyond the grant. Trained staff can continue facilitating reading circles and basic blockchain support after funding ends. Physical presence in trusted institutions legitimizes the project.



Success criteria:

-  3 libraries with signed MOUs and active corners

-  3 trained staff members (completed 4-hour training)

-  Each library hosts at least 2 events during project period





DIMENSION 3: CARDANO ADOPTION



Metric 3.1: 200 new Cardano wallets created via project CTAs



Target: 200 first-time Cardano wallets created by project participants  

Measurement: Tracked through dedicated project landing pages with opt-in forms (privacy-respecting)  

Rationale: Wallet creation is the critical first step. 200 represents ~35% of our 576-member community taking action—an ambitious but realistic conversion rate given hands-on support. We'll instrument this through:

- Dedicated wallet setup landing pages with unique UTM codes

- Opt-in form asking "Did you create your first Cardano wallet through Paper Thoughts?" (voluntary)

- In-person clinic tracking (staff-assisted setups counted)



Success criteria:

-  200+ wallets (exceeds target)

-  150-199 wallets (strong performance)

-  100-149 wallets (indicates support gaps, but still valuable)



Privacy note: All tracking is voluntary opt-in; we never require wallet addresses or personal data.





Metric 3.2: 300 NFTs minted total (micro-journals + badges + comics)



Target: 300 total mints across all NFT offerings  

Measurement: On-chain data (public mint counts)  

Breakdown:

- Micro-journal NFTs (3 editions × 50 mints each) = 150

- Participation badges (cohort completions, contest entries) = 100

- Comic finalist/winner NFTs = 50



Rationale: Minting is participants' first active on-chain transaction—the moment blockchain becomes real. 300 mints from 200 wallets (1.5 mints per wallet average) is realistic given some participants will mint multiple items.



Success criteria:

-  300+ mints (people are collecting multiple items—strong engagement)

-  200-299 mints (solid first-time experience)

-  150-199 mints (technical barriers likely present)





Metric 3.3: 100 wallets stake ADA within 2 months of creation



Target: 100 of the 200 new wallets successfully delegate to a stake pool  

Measurement: Self-reported via follow-up survey + encouraged screenshots (voluntary)  

Rationale: Staking demonstrates commitment beyond curiosity—participants understand Cardano's governance/rewards model and are taking a second on-chain action. 50% conversion (from wallet creation to staking) is ambitious, reflecting our follow-up support workshops.



Success criteria:

-  100+ staking wallets (exceptional follow-through)

-  75-99 staking wallets (strong outcome)

-  50-74 staking wallets (people minted but didn't continue—need better staking education)



Tracking method: Post-wallet-creation email sequence (with opt-in) asking "Have you staked yet?" with link to staking guide. Incentivize reporting with entry into final raffle (small book prizes).

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
THE PROBLEM (Restated for clarity):  



Two parallel crises exist:   (A)   Communities worldwide are losing irreplaceable cultural knowledge as elders pass away and oral traditions fade, with few accessible tools for respectful preservation.   (B)   Cardano needs to reach everyday, non-technical people but lacks culturally meaningful entry points—current onboarding is abstract, technical, and unappealing to people whose interests lie in heritage, storytelling, and community rather than finance or development.



  OUR SOLUTION:  



Paper Thoughts — Read, Write, Chain creates a 9-month cultural program that solves both problems simultaneously by making cultural preservation the  reason  people encounter Cardano, not an afterthought. We design activities that have intrinsic value (preserving elders' stories) and gently introduce blockchain as a tool that enhances that preservation—permanence, accessibility, verification—without requiring technical expertise.



  HOW THE SOLUTION WORKS: THE JOURNEY  



  PHASE 1: AWARENESS & TRUST-BUILDING (Months 1-2)  



We begin with  familiar, low-risk activities  that establish credibility and community trust:



  Monthly Reading Salons (ongoing):   We host moderated online discussions about storytelling, memory, and heritage—topics our 576-member book club already loves. Early salons feature guest authors or historians discussing oral tradition preservation. No blockchain mentioned yet. We're simply doing what book clubs do: reading, discussing, connecting.



  Library partnerships launch:   We approach 3 local libraries with a compelling pitch: "We want to help your community preserve local stories and activate your space with reading circles." Libraries love community programming, and we offer free labor and materials. We establish "Paper Thoughts Corners" with printed reading guides and oral-history how-tos. This creates physical presence and institutional credibility.



  First cohort recruitment:   Toward the end of month 2, salon attendees and community members receive an invitation: "Want to go deeper? Join our Cultural Preservation Writing Cohort—learn to interview elders and document their stories for publication." We emphasize: no experience needed, full support provided, your work will be published.



 Problem addressed:  People distrust "blockchain projects" but trust cultural/educational initiatives backed by libraries. We build legitimacy first, create value first, earn the right to introduce Cardano later.



  PHASE 2: SKILL-BUILDING & PRODUCTION (Months 3-5)  



  Cultural Preservation Writing Cohorts (3 over 9 months):   This is the heart of our solution. Each 6-week cohort trains 12-15 participants in:

- Oral-history interviewing ethics and techniques

- Recording and transcribing audio

- Writing/editing for publication

- Copyright, consent, and cultural sensitivity



Participants identify elders in their lives or communities (grandparents, longtime neighbors, community leaders) and conduct recorded interviews. Weekly Zoom workshops provide peer feedback and editorial guidance. A professional editor mentors participants to polish their transcripts into readable narratives.



  Why this works:   Cohorts create accountability, community, and genuine skill development. Participants aren't just attending a one-off event—they're completing a structured learning experience and producing something they're proud of. The cultural preservation work is  real  and  valuable , independent of any blockchain component.



  Micro-journal production:   At the end of each cohort (months 3, 5, 8), we publish a beautifully designed micro-journal featuring the best documented stories. Each contributor receives print copies and a PDF. Journals are distributed to partner libraries and made freely downloadable online.



 Problem addressed:  Communities lose oral knowledge because there's no clear pathway from "I should record Grandma's stories" to "I've published Grandma's stories in a real publication." We provide that pathway with training, support, and a professional output. Elders feel honored; families feel proud; communities have new cultural resources.



---



  PHASE 3: GENTLE BLOCKCHAIN INTRODUCTION (Months 3-9, overlapping)  



Here's where Cardano enters—but critically, it enters as an  enhancement , not a requirement.



  Post-cohort completion celebration:   When a cohort publishes its micro-journal, we host a celebration event (online + library screenings). We present contributors with their publication and then say:



 "You've created something permanent and valuable. We're going to do one more thing to make it even more lasting: we're going to mint a limited commemorative edition on Cardano, a blockchain that can preserve this forever. Think of it like a digital certificate that says, 'I contributed to this cultural preservation work,' and it can never be faked or lost. Would you like to learn how to claim yours?" 



  Guided minting clinics:   Immediately following each cohort, we run a hands-on minting clinic. Participants join a Zoom call (or meet in person at a library) where staff walk them step-by-step through:

1. Downloading a Cardano wallet (we recommend Lace or Eternl—user-friendly options)

2. Securing their seed phrase (we emphasize safety, provide printable templates)

3. Receiving a small amount of test ADA (we send ~3 ADA to cover minting fees)

4. Navigating to our custom minting page

5. Clicking "mint" and watching their NFT appear in their wallet



  Critical design decision:   We make this  optional . Some elders or technophobic participants may say, "I just want the printed journal, thank you." That's fine—they've still contributed to cultural preservation. But for curious participants, we provide real-time troubleshooting, encouragement, and community support. "Everyone's doing it together; we've got your back."



  Why this works:   The blockchain action has  meaning —it's not minting a random Bored Ape; it's claiming credit for cultural work they personally did. The timing is perfect—motivation is high right after seeing their name in print. And crucially, they're not alone—live support removes fear.



 Problem addressed:  Cardano onboarding fails when it's abstract ("set up a wallet to try staking") or risky-feeling ("buy crypto"). We make it concrete ("mint a token representing your real cultural contribution") and safe (guided, live support in a trusted context).



  PHASE 4: DEEPENING ENGAGEMENT (Months 6-9)  



  Staking workshops:   For participants who successfully minted, we run follow-up workshops introducing staking. We frame it as:  "That small amount of ADA we sent you? You can actually put it to work supporting the Cardano network and earn rewards. Let us show you how." 



We demonstrate stake pool selection (emphasizing mission-driven pools), walk through delegation, and explain rewards. Target: 50% of wallet-creators also stake.



  Comic contest:   Midway through the project, we announce an open call for comics/illustrations based on collected oral histories. Artists (from our community or beyond) submit visual interpretations of elders' stories. This serves multiple purposes:

- Engages a younger, visual-arts demographic

- Creates additional shareable content

- Generates excitement and cross-promotion



Contest finalists receive NFT badges; winners get their comics professionally animated and minted. This introduces a new cohort (artists) to Cardano through creative work rather than technical onboarding.



  Library help-desk hours:   Throughout months 6-9, partner libraries host weekly "blockchain help hours" where trained staff or volunteers answer questions, assist with wallet recovery, or help people mint additional items. This creates sustained support infrastructure.



 Problem addressed:  One-time onboarding isn't enough—people need ongoing support to become confident blockchain users. By embedding support in libraries (trusted, free, accessible), we reduce abandonment and build genuine capability.



  PHASE 5: CELEBRATION & SUSTAINABILITY (Month 9)  



  Community screening event:   We host a culminating event showcasing:

- All three micro-journals (physical display)

- The oral-history digital archive (live demo)

- Animated comic winners (premiere screening)

- "Blockchain 101" info table for newcomers



This event celebrates cultural outputs first, Cardano second—but attendees learn, "Oh, all of this is preserved on Cardano forever."



  Final impact report & replication toolkit:   We publish a comprehensive open-source guide: "How to run a cultural preservation + Cardano onboarding program in your community." Every template, script, lesson plan, and tech walkthrough is CC-licensed for replication.



  Library partnerships continue:   Trained library staff can continue hosting reading circles and basic blockchain support after our grant ends—sustainability built in.



 Problem addressed:  Grant-funded projects often die after funding. By open-sourcing everything and building institutional partnerships, we create lasting infrastructure.





  HOW THIS SOLUTION ADDRESSES BOTH PROBLEMS:  



  Problem A (Cultural preservation):  

- ✅ 30 elder interviews recorded = irreplaceable knowledge saved

- ✅ 3 published micro-journals = accessible cultural resources

- ✅ Digital archive = searchable, permanent, free

- ✅ Training provided = community capacity-building

- ✅ Respectful process = elders honored, consent-centered



  Problem B (Cardano adoption):  

- ✅ 200 new wallets = non-technical people successfully onboarded

- ✅ 300 NFTs minted = meaningful first on-chain transactions

- ✅ 100 staking wallets = deeper ecosystem participation

- ✅ Library legitimacy = institutional validation of Cardano

- ✅ Replicable model = scalable blueprint for other communities

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
Our project creates impact across multiple layers of the Cardano ecosystem, from individual users to global narrative positioning. Here's how Paper Thoughts influences the wider community:



IMPACT LAYER 1: USER BASE EXPANSION (New demographics)



Bringing in underserved audiences:



Cardano's current user base skews toward tech-savvy, financially motivated individuals. Our project specifically targets three demographics Cardano struggles to reach:



(A) Cultural stewards and heritage enthusiasts: People aged 35-65 who care deeply about preserving community memory but have zero crypto experience. These are educators, librarians, retired teachers, community historians—literate, civic-minded people who would enthusiastically embrace Cardano if they understood its cultural utility. We bring 200 of these people on-chain.



(B) Elders (60+): Often excluded from blockchain conversations entirely. By honoring their knowledge and showing how Cardano preserves their stories, we create intergenerational awareness. When a 75-year-old grandmother proudly tells her grandchildren, "My recipes are on the blockchain forever," that's powerful cultural marketing.



(C) Young creatives: Through our comic contest, we engage artists, illustrators, and animators who see Cardano as a platform for cultural expression, not just financial transactions. This seeds awareness in creative industries that could drive future NFT/cultural projects.



 Why this matters to wider Cardano community: A blockchain is only as strong as its user diversity. Monocultural communities (all DeFi traders, all developers) are fragile. By bringing in culture-focused users, we:

- Increase governance participation diversity (different values, priorities)

- Reduce price-speculation volatility (mission-driven users hold longer)

- Create network effects (cultural users invite other cultural users)



Target: 200 new wallets is small in absolute terms but represents a proof of concept that this demographic can be reached at scale.





IMPACT LAYER 2: NARRATIVE & POSITIONING (What Cardano is "for")



Answering the "So what?" question:



Mainstream skepticism of blockchain centers on: "But what's it actually FOR beyond speculation?" Cultural preservation is an unimpeachable answer. When journalists, policymakers, or everyday people ask, "Why does Cardano matter?", our project provides a story:



 "In Nigeria, a community book club used Cardano to permanently preserve 30 elders' oral histories before they were lost forever. Families can now access their ancestors' stories, researchers can study local folklore, and artists are transforming these stories into animated films—all verifiable and permanent on-chain." 



  This narrative shifts Cardano's positioning from:  

- ❌ "A cryptocurrency" → ✅ "A cultural preservation infrastructure"

- ❌ "A DeFi platform" → ✅ "A public good permanence layer"

- ❌ "For traders/developers" → ✅ "For communities and families"



  Why this matters:   Cardano competes with Ethereum, Solana, and others on technical specs. But on  purpose and values , Cardano can differentiate. Cultural projects like ours become proof points that Cardano is the blockchain for long-term, meaningful applications—not just fast transactions or DeFi yields.



  Expected reach:   Each animated comic we produce (2 total) could reach 5,000-10,000 views online. Every time someone shares it with "This was preserved on Cardano," that's brand awareness in non-crypto spaces (education, cultural, arts communities).



  IMPACT LAYER 3: ECOSYSTEM TOOLING & BEST PRACTICES (Replicability)  



  Creating an open-source blueprint:  



We're not just running one project—we're building a model  that others can copy. Our final deliverable includes a comprehensive replication toolkit:

- All workshop templates (oral-history training, wallet setup guides)

- Minting clinic scripts and troubleshooting FAQs

- Library partnership MOUs and pitch decks

- Marketing materials and social media templates

- Lessons learned and failure analysis



All materials are CC-licensed (Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike), meaning anyone globally can adapt them.



  Why this matters:   If our model works, it can scale exponentially:

-   100 similar projects   worldwide (different regions, cultures, languages) could onboard   20,000 new users   using our playbook

- Each project generates culturally specific content (Japanese folklore, Kenyan oral histories, Appalachian storytelling) that attracts diverse audiences

- Cardano becomes known as  the  blockchain for cultural preservation—a unique, defensible market position



  We're not just bringing 200 users—we're creating a bridge that could eventually bring 200,000.  



  Expected impact:   Realistically, 5-10 communities will attempt to replicate within the first year post-project. If even 3 succeed, that's 600 additional wallets from our work.



  IMPACT LAYER 4: INSTITUTIONAL PARTNERSHIPS (Legitimacy)  



  Mainstreaming Cardano through libraries:  



Our 3 library partnerships are small but symbolically significant. Libraries are trusted civic institutions—when they endorse something, mainstream communities listen. By hosting "Cardano minting clinics" and "blockchain help hours" in libraries, we:

- Legitimize Cardano as a public good (not a speculative scheme)

- Create precedent for other institutions (schools, museums, community centers)

- Demonstrate regulatory-friendly use cases (cultural, educational, non-financial)



  Why this matters:   Cardano's long-term success depends on institutional adoption—governments, universities, NGOs. But institutions are risk-averse and need proof that blockchain has non-financial applications. Our library partnerships are small-scale pilots that prove the concept.



  Future potential:   If successful, we can pitch to:

- National library systems (scale to 100+ branches)

- University archives (student projects documenting campus oral histories)

- Museums (provenance tracking for cultural artifacts)

- UNESCO (cultural heritage preservation grants)



  One successful library partnership today = blueprint for 1,000 partnerships tomorrow.  



  IMPACT LAYER 5: COMMUNITY CULTURE & VALUES (Who Cardano is "for")  



  Shaping ecosystem culture:  



Every new user brings values and norms. By intentionally onboarding culture-focused, mission-driven people, we influence Cardano's community culture in positive ways:



  (A) Governance participation:   Cultural stewards care about long-term ecosystem health (preserving public goods, funding education). They're likely to participate in Catalyst voting and Project Catalyst proposals—deepening decentralized governance.



  (B) Reduced toxicity:   People who join through cultural preservation are less likely to engage in "wen moon" speculation or tribal maximalism. They elevate discourse toward utility and impact.



  (C) Mission alignment:   Cardano positions itself as the "sustainable, research-driven, long-term" blockchain. Cultural preservationists align perfectly with this ethos—they're patient, methodical, and focused on legacy.



  Why this matters:   Blockchain communities often become echo chambers dominated by a narrow set of voices (traders, developers). Diversifying who participates improves decision-making, reduces groupthink, and makes Cardano more resilient.



  Target: 120 repeat participants become active community members   who might later propose their own Catalyst projects, support others' proposals, or evangelize Cardano in cultural spaces.



  IMPACT LAYER 6: CONTENT & MEDIA (Shareable stories)  



  Creating Cardano content that non-crypto people want to engage with:  



Most Cardano content is technical (developer tutorials, DeFi explainers) or financial (price analysis, staking guides). This content doesn't travel outside crypto circles. Our project produces:

-   2 animated shorts (2-5 min each):   Beautiful, emotionally resonant films about oral traditions—shareable on Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, YouTube. People who would never watch "Cardano Explained" will watch a 3-minute animated folktale.

-   3 micro-journals:   Designed, printed artifacts that feel like indie literary magazines—appealing to readers, writers, and cultural enthusiasts.

-   Oral-history archive:   A searchable digital resource useful to researchers, educators, families—driving organic traffic to a Cardano-adjacent project.



  Why this matters:   Cardano needs content that attracts  inbound interest  from non-crypto audiences. Every animated comic that goes semi-viral (even just 10,000 views) is 10,000 people learning "Cardano preserves culture"—free brand awareness in spaces Cardano marketing rarely reaches.



  Expected reach:   Conservatively, our outputs could generate 50,000 impressions across social media and educational channels over 12 months post-project.



  IMPACT LAYER 7: ECOSYSTEM FUNDING STRATEGY (Proof of concept for Catalyst)  



  Demonstrating that non-technical projects can onboard users effectively:  



Project Catalyst overwhelmingly funds technical development, infrastructure, and DeFi tools—necessary, but insufficient for mass adoption. Our project proves that  cultural projects can deliver meaningful Cardano adoption metrics (wallets, minting, staking) while producing intrinsic value.



  Why this matters for Catalyst reviewers:  

- Sets precedent for funding more cultural/social projects

- Shows that "soft" activities (book clubs, storytelling) can achieve "hard" metrics (wallet creation, on-chain transactions)

- Encourages other proposers to think creatively about non-technical onboarding



  If our project succeeds, future Catalyst rounds might see proposals for:  

- Music preservation projects (blues archives, indigenous songs)

- Culinary heritage documentation (family recipes minted as NFTs)

- Language revitalization (endangered languages preserved on-chain)

- Oral history projects in refugee camps, diaspora communities, rural areas



  We're not just proposing one project—we're opening a new category of Catalyst funding: "Cultural Onboarding."

sub_fields.title: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.description: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.answer:
Core strengths



Community-building track record. Paper Thoughts has run 3 in-house writing contests, 2 book fairs, a Book & Arts Festival with the Faculty of Art (ABU), and regular creatives’ hangouts with Creative Connect. That experience proves we can design events, recruit participants, and follow through on public deliverables.



Institutional credibility. Dr. Abdulhamid Liman Gambo (ABU University Librarian) is our Grand Patron and the Faculty of Art is hosting our festival — both lend institutional legitimacy that reduces perceived risk and increases uptake among non-crypto communities.



Cultural & creative leadership. Team members include recognised poets, a creative director, and community managers who speak directly to the target audiences (elders, cultural stewards, creatives).



Practical operations capability. You (project lead) have event coordination and community management experience; we have local partners (Creative Connect) and volunteers who can run workshops, minting clinics, and community outreach.



Accountability systems we will use



Transparent budgeting & reporting: monthly budget updates and a final audited spend report, shared publicly and with Catalyst reviewers. All expenditures logged and summarized in milestone reports.



On-chain proofs: where possible, minting, publication or grant disbursements will include on-chain receipts so results (e.g., wallets minted, artworks recorded) are verifiable.



Institutional MOUs: signed MOUs with host libraries and the Faculty of Art define responsibilities, venues, and deliverables — these formalize expectations and provide third-party validation.



Open-source deliverables: replication toolkit, templates, and lessons learned will be CC-BY-SA and published openly so reviewers can verify outputs.



Milestone-based governance: clear milestones with acceptance criteria, monthly progress notes, and a final project sign-off from the Grand Patron and Advisor.



Community feedback loops: post-event surveys, participant lists, and public archive access ensure community validation of impact.



Risk & mitigation plan: contingency funds, backup venues, and simple escalation procedures for logistics or partner issues.

sub_fields.title: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.description: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.answer:
Direct onboarding & measurable outcomes



Target onboarding: 200 new wallets from cultural audiences (elders, librarians, cultural stewards, creatives).



Cost per wallet ≈ 200 ADA (40,000 ADA / 200 wallets). This is a defensible acquisition cost for long-term, mission-driven users who are likely to hold, engage in governance, and seed future cultural projects.



Repeat engagement target: 120 repeat participants who become active community members (workshop leaders, local advocates).



High-leverage, low-risk investments



Institutional adoption lever: Library partnerships and ABU involvement reduce adoption friction among mainstream audiences and create templates for scaling to school systems, national library networks, and museums.



Content that travels: Two animated shorts + micro-journals function as shareable cultural assets that explain Cardano’s value in human terms; these are high ROI for brand positioning (educational and cultural channels where crypto messaging rarely reaches).



Replication potential: The CC-BY-SA toolkit allows easy replication; if replicated by 100 communities, the same model could bring 20,000+ wallets with relatively low marginal cost — multiplying the initial investment.



System-level benefits for Cardano



Narrative diversification: Moves Cardano’s public image from “trading/DeFi” to “cultural preservation and public goods,” making the ecosystem attractive to institutions and mainstream audiences. That reputational gain is hard to buy with ads but highly valuable for sustainable adoption and regulation-friendly positioning.



Catalyst multiplier effect: Successful delivery sets precedence and evidence that cultural/non-technical proposals can produce on-chain adoption; this can unlock more diverse Catalyst funding in future rounds.



Governance quality uplift: Culture-focused users and institutional partners typically vote for long-term, public-good priorities — improving proposal quality and reducing short-term speculation-driven governance pressure.



Concrete value metrics we will report



Wallets created and number of on-chain transactions tied to the project



Number of oral histories archived (target: 30+ elders recorded) and accessible via the public archive



Views / impressions of animated shorts and social share metrics (target conservative reach: 5k–10k per animation)



Number of partner institutions engaged (target: 3 library partners + Faculty of Art)



Toolkit downloads & replication enquiries within 9 months
